DataElement.preferredDefinition: The DNA mismatch repair system recognizes and repairs erroneous incorporation of bases that can occur during DNA replication and recombination and in response to DNA damage. Mutations in the mismatch repair system can lead to increased risk of cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair.

Concepts.definition: A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair.

Property.preferredDefinition: A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: A condition or state at a particular time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Abnormalities that occur in human cells and tissues and models of human cancer.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated to support HCMI Brain Tumors_10.11.17_ghd

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A condition or state at a particular time.

PermissibleValues.value: MMR loss evidence hypermutation phenotype (>10 mutations/Mb)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mismatch Repair Deficiency Evidence Hypermutation Phenotype

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mismatch Repair Deficiency Evidence Hypermutation Phenotype
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating that a cellular sample has high microsatellite instability and/or a functional loss of a protein involved in the DNA mismatch repair process.: Knowledge on which to base belief.: A genetic marker marked by the presence of mutations in genes that maintain genomic integrity, which leads to greatly increased rates of mutation for the rest of the genome and may induce malignant transformation.

Concepts.definition: A finding indicating that a cellular sample has high microsatellite instability and/or a functional loss of a protein involved in the DNA mismatch repair process.
Knowledge on which to base belief.

A genetic marker marked by the presence of mutations in genes that maintain genomic integrity, which leads to greatly increased rates of mutation for the rest of the genome and may induce malignant transformation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Negation Evidence Mismatch Repair Gene Mutation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Negation Evidence Mismatch Repair Gene Mutation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: Knowledge on which to base belief.: A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Knowledge on which to base belief.
A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair.

PermissibleValues.value: Evidence of MMR protein loss by IHC
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Evidence Mismatch Repair Protein Loss Immunohistochemistry Staining Method

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Evidence Mismatch Repair Protein Loss Immunohistochemistry Staining Method
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Knowledge on which to base belief.: A DNA repair protein family that is comprised of the active components of the DNA mismatch repair system.: A gradual decline in amount or activity.: Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.

Concepts.definition: Knowledge on which to base belief.
A DNA repair protein family that is comprised of the active components of the DNA mismatch repair system.
A gradual decline in amount or activity.

Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.

PermissibleValues.value: Evidence of MMR mutation by sequencing
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Evidence Mismatch Repair Gene Mutation Gene Mapping, Human

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Evidence Mismatch Repair Gene Mutation Gene Mapping, Human
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Knowledge on which to base belief.: A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair.: Determination of the relative positions of human genes on a DNA molecule (chromosome or plasmid) and of the distance, in linkage units or physical units, between them.

Concepts.definition: Knowledge on which to base belief.
A change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene involved in DNA mismatch repair.
Determination of the relative positions of human genes on a DNA molecule (chromosome or plasmid) and of the distance, in linkage units or physical units, between them.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Abnormalities that occur in human cells and tissues and models of human cancer.
